name: Bodyweight Squat
description: A foundational lower-body movement that teaches proper squat mechanics. Perfect for beginners to learn joint alignment and knee tracking before adding weight. This exercise builds strength in your legs and glutes while improving mobility.
tips: Keep your feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly turned out
Lower down as if sitting in a chair, pushing hips back
Keep knees aligned with your toes - avoid letting them collapse inward
Maintain a neutral spine - don't round your back
Push through your heels to return to standing
Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout
commonMistakes: Knees tracking too far forward past toes

name: Deadlift
description: A fundamental posterior chain exercise that teaches the hip hinge pattern. Essential for building glutes, hamstrings, and lower back strength. Perfect for learning proper spine alignment and posterior chain activation.
tips: Start with feet hip-width apart, bar close to shins
Hinge at the hips, pushing hips back while keeping chest up
Maintain a neutral spine throughout - no rounding
Keep the bar close to your body as you lift
Drive through your heels and squeeze glutes at the top
Lower with control, maintaining spine alignment
commonMistakes: Not engaging glutes and hamstrings properly

name: Push-Up
description: A classic upper-body push pattern that strengthens chest, triceps, and core. Can be easily modified for beginners (knee or wall push-ups) or progressed for advanced users. Great for learning proper body alignment and controlled movement.
tips: Start in plank position with hands directly under shoulders
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels
Lower your body until chest nearly touches the floor
Push back up to starting position with control
Engage your core throughout to maintain body alignment
For beginners: try knee push-ups or wall push-ups
For progression: elevate feet or add tempo variations
commonMistakes: Sagging hips or lifting hips too high
Hands too wide or too narrow
Not going through full range of motion

name: Bicep Curl
description: A simple isolation movement perfect for beginners to understand controlled, focused motion. Teaches proper form for arm exercises and helps build bicep strength and muscle mind connection.
tips: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Keep elbows close to your sides
Curl weight up with control, squeezing biceps at top
Lower slowly with control - don't let gravity do the work
Avoid swinging or using momentum
Keep your core engaged and shoulders relaxed
commonMistakes: Using too much weight causing form breakdown

name: Plank
description: An isometric core stability exercise that builds strength throughout your entire body. Minimal motion allows focus on perfect alignment and posture. Great for teaching core engagement and body awareness.
tips: Start in push-up position on forearms
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels
Engage your core and glutes - imagine pulling belly button to spine
Keep shoulders directly over elbows
Hold for 20-60 seconds, breathing normally
Don't let hips sag or lift too high
Focus on maintaining perfect alignment
commonMistakes: Hips lifted too high (butt in air)

name: Lunge
description: A single-leg stability exercise that improves balance, coordination, and leg strength. Great for addressing muscle imbalances and teaching proper front/back plane movement. Challenges each leg independently.
tips: Step forward with one leg into a split stance
Lower your hips until both knees are bent at 90 degrees
Keep front knee aligned with ankle, not past toes
Back knee should hover just above the ground
Keep torso upright, core engaged
Push through front heel to return to starting position
Alternate legs for balanced training
commonMistakes: Front knee tracking too far forward

name: Glute Bridge
description: A beginner-friendly posterior chain exercise that's perfect for learning glute activation. Low intimidation factor makes it ideal for those new to strength training. Great for highlighting muscle activation and teaching hip extension.
tips: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on floor
Place feet hip-width apart, close to glutes
Engage your glutes and lift hips up
Create a straight line from knees to shoulders
Squeeze glutes at the top, hold for 1-2 seconds
Lower with control
Focus on feeling glutes do the work, not lower back
commonMistakes: Overarching lower back instead of using glutes

name: Overhead Shoulder Press
description: An upper-body compound movement that builds shoulder and tricep strength while challenging core stability. Excellent for teaching proper posture and overhead movement patterns. Great for functional strength.
tips: Start with weight at shoulder height, palms facing forward
Keep core engaged and maintain upright posture
Press weight overhead until arms are fully extended
Keep shoulders down, don't let them shrug up
Lower with control back to shoulder height
Maintain neutral spine - avoid arching back excessively
Breathe out on the press up
commonMistakes: Pressing forward instead of straight up

name: Pull-Up / Assisted Pull-Up
description: An upper-body pull pattern that builds back, lat, and arm strength. Shows the concept of progression - start with assisted variations and work toward full pull-ups. An aspirational skill that motivates users to build strength over time.
tips: Start with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Hang with arms fully extended, engage your core
Pull your body up until chin clears the bar
Lower with control - don't drop down
For beginners: use resistance bands or assisted pull-up machine
Focus on pulling with your back muscles, not just arms
Keep shoulders down and away from ears
commonMistakes: Not going through full range of motion
progression: Start with dead hangs to build grip strength

name: Kettlebell Swing
description: A dynamic hinge movement that develops power, rhythm, and timing. Combines strength and cardiovascular benefits while teaching proper hip drive. Advanced movement that introduces explosive power patterns and smooth motion arcs.
tips: Start with feet slightly wider than hip-width
Hinge at hips, keeping back flat and chest up
Drive hips forward explosively to swing kettlebell up
Kettlebell should reach chest height, not overhead
Let gravity bring it back down between legs
Maintain rhythm and timing - smooth, not jerky
Keep core engaged throughout the movement
Focus on hip drive, not arm pull
commonMistakes: Using arms to lift instead of hip drive
rhythm: The swing should have a smooth, rhythmic flow - explosive up, controlled down
